factoid: Rostóv's horse pawed the frozen ground.
Rostóv's horse pricked its ears at the noise.
Rostóv's horse looked at the lights.
The shouting grew louder and became a general roar.
The general roar could only be produced by an army of several thousand men.
The lights spread farther and farther.
The lights probably spread along the line of the French camp.
Rostóv no longer wanted to sleep.
The gay triumphant shouting of the enemy army had a stimulating effect on Rostóv.
Rostóv heard "Vive l’Empereur! l’Empereur!" distinctly.
Rostóv said to the hussar beside him that they cannot be far off, probably just beyond the stream.
The hussar sighed without replying.
The hussar coughed angrily.
The sound of horse hooves approaching at a trot along the line of hussars was heard.
The figure of a sergeant of hussars suddenly appeared out of the foggy darkness.
The sergeant of hussars loomed huge as an elephant.
The sergeant said "Your honor, the generals!" while riding up to Rostóv.
Rostóv rode with the sergeant toward the fires and shouts.
Rostóv rode with the sergeant to meet some mounted men who were riding along the line.
One of the mounted men was on a white horse.
Prince Bagratión and Prince Dolgorúkov with their adjutants had come to witness the curious phenomenon of the lights and shouts in the enemy's camp.
Rostóv rode up to Prince Bagratión.
Rostóv reported to Prince Bagratión.
Rostóv joined the adjutants listening to what the generals were saying.
Prince Dolgorúkov said to Prince Bagratión that it is nothing but a trick.
Prince Dolgorúkov said that the enemy has retreated.
Prince Dolgorúkov said that the enemy ordered the rearguard to kindle fires and make noise to deceive us.
Prince Bagratión said "Hardly".
Prince Bagratión said he saw them this evening on that knoll.
Prince Bagratión said that if they had retreated, they would have withdrawn from that too.
Prince Bagratión addressed Rostóv as "Officer" and asked if the enemy's skirmishers were still there.
Rostóv replied that they were there this evening.
Rostóv replied that now he does not know.
Rostóv replied that he could go with some of his hussars to see.
Prince Bagratión stopped.
Prince Bagratión tried to see Rostóv's face in the mist.
Prince Bagratión said "Well, go and see."
Rostóv said "Yes, sir."
Rostóv spurred his horse.
Rostóv called to Sergeant Fédchenko and two other hussars.
Rostóv told them to follow him.
Rostóv trotted downhill in the direction from which the shouting came.
Rostóv felt frightened.
Rostóv felt pleased.
Rostóv was riding alone with three hussars into a mysterious and dangerous misty distance where no one had been before him.
Prince Bagratión called to Rostóv from the hill not to go beyond the stream.
Rostóv pretended not to hear Prince Bagratión.
Rostóv did not stop but rode on.
Rostóv continually mistook bushes for trees.
Rostóv continually mistook gullies for men.
Rostóv continually discovered his mistakes.
After descending the hill at a trot, Rostóv no longer saw our own fires.
After descending the hill at a trot, Rostóv no longer saw enemy's fires.
After descending the hill at a trot, Rostóv heard the shouting of the French more loudly and distinctly.
In the valley, Rostóv saw something like a river.
When Rostóv reached it, he found it was a road.
After coming out onto the road, Rostóv reined in his horse.
Rostóv hesitated whether to ride along the road or cross it and ride over the black field up the hillside.
Keeping to the road which gleamed white in the mist would have been safer.
It would have been easier to see people coming along the road.
Rostóv said "Follow me!"
Rostóv crossed the road.
Rostóv began riding up the hill at a gallop toward the point where the French pickets had been standing that evening.
One of the hussars behind Rostóv cried "Your honor, there he is!"
Before Rostóv had time to make out what the black thing was that had suddenly appeared in the fog, there was a flash.
Then there was a report.
Then a bullet whizzed high up in the mist with a plaintive sound and passed out of hearing.
Another musket missed fire but flashed in the pan.
Rostóv turned his horse and galloped back.
Four more reports followed at intervals.
The bullets passed somewhere in the fog singing in different tones.
Rostóv reined in his horse.
The horse's spirits had risen, like Rostóv's, at the firing.
Rostóv went back at a footpace.
A merry voice was saying "Well, some more! Some more!" in Rostóv's soul.
No more shots came.
Only when approaching Prince Bagratión did Rostóv let his horse gallop again.
Rostóv rode up to Prince Bagratión with his hand at the salute.
Prince Dolgorúkov was still insisting that the French had retreated.
Prince Dolgorúkov was still insisting that the French had only lit fires to deceive us.
